Became Executive Chairman of the Saha-Union conglomerate and a widely respected business leader.

Installed as Prime Minister by General Suchinda after a coup. Focused on deregulation, cutting red tape, and fostering free enterprise. Improved foreign relations with China, Japan, Laos, Cambodia, and Vietnam, but faced criticism for a soft stance towards Burma's military junta.
Invited to serve as Prime Minister after military take-over in February 1991

Chosen as the acceptable leader after a successful coup in 1991, Anand launched reforms including expanding press freedom, combating AIDS, and promoting transparency. He was called again to assume the interim premiership in 1992 after pro-democracy demonstrations.

career_events.role: Chairman of the Board of Directors
career_events.description: Elected to the position

Led administration focused on reforms in education, public health, exports, agriculture, industry, environment, and living conditions. Implemented significant taxation reforms, including VAT introduction and corporate tax reduction. Established ASEAN Free Trade Area (AFTA) and effective anti-AIDS/HIV policy. Oversaw electricity market reform and infrastructure projects.
Rejoined after the 1992 general elections; resigned in 2002.
Involved in public-service activities, including chairing the constitution drafting committee.

career_events.role: Member and Chairman of the Drafting Committee
career_events.description: Oversaw the drafting of the 'Peoples' Constitution' of 1997, which included reforms such as decentralization of government, establishment of independent agencies, and mechanisms to increase political stability.
Elected to the Thai Constitution Drafting Assembly and appointed Chairman, leading to the successful ratification of the new Constitution.
